title: Christmas Sounds Can Be Hard for Some People
summary: Christmas is a fun time for many, but for people with misophonia, it can be very tough. Misophonia means some sounds make them feel very upset. Lottie, a 23-year-old, wears earplugs during Christmas dinner because noises like chewing and slurping make her panic and tense up. She has had this since she was 16. In the UK, almost one in five people have misophonia. Sounds from mouths or fingers can cause distress. Jenna, a 21-year-old student, uses earphones to cope. She feels angry or anxious around family. Christmas can be a nightmare for them because they want to be with family but find the sounds overwhelming. They might avoid social events to feel better.

background_read: Misophonia is a condition where everyday sounds, like chewing or breathing, can make people feel very upset or angry. It's common, affecting many people in the UK. During holidays like Christmas, family gatherings can be hard because there are lots of noises. People with misophonia might use earplugs or earphones to feel better. They love their families but struggle with the sounds, which can make them avoid parties. Understanding this helps us be kinder to those who find noises difficult.
